lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Rendering a component depends on its state and props. Side effects break this concept by involving external actions like fetching data.

useEffect is a React hook that lets our components perform side effects.

lessons.title: Lesson #2
lessons.interactiveContent:
To use the useEffect hook, we import the named export from the React package.

The useEffect hook will run after every render.

Make sure to pick { followed by useEffect and then }, useEffect.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
To use the hook, we start by calling the useEffect function after importing it.

Make sure to pick useEffect, followed by useEffect, and finally ().

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We pass an arrow function as the argument to the useEffect function.

The useEffect hook will run after every render.

Make sure to pick () followed by => and then {, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Inside the passed function, we can add the code we want to be executed when useEffect is triggered.

Make sure to pick { followed by console and then ., log, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #2 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use the useEffect hook in combination with other hooks such as useState.

Inside the callback function, we pass to useEffect, we can update state variables. This is useful when useEffect calls an API, for example.

Make sure to pick { useState, useEffect } followed by useState and then useEffect, setWeather.

lessons.title: Lesson #7
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use useEffect to log "Welcome to the cinema!" to the console after rendering.

Make sure to type useEffect.

lessons.title: Lesson #8
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will the following code display in the console?

HelloSomethingNothingWhat's up

Make sure to pick Hello.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Import the needed hook to change the text of a state variable and display "Start!" after rendering.

Make sure to type useEffect.

lessons.title: Lesson #10 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
When will useEffect(() => { console.log("Hi")}) be called?

After every render of the componentNeverOnce after the initial renderEvery time a state variable is updated

After every render of the component.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
So far, you've learned that useEffect runs its callback after every render.

We can also make it run based on certain conditions, such as whenever a state variable is updated based on user input.

lessons.title: Lesson #4
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we use the useEffect hook without passing additional parameters, the callback will be rendered after every render.

Click the button to see that the updated state leads to a render, which leads to an execution of the useEffect hook.

Make sure to pick useEffect, followed by useEffect.

lessons.title: Lesson #4 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In addition to the callback function, we can pass a dependency array as the second argument.

If we pass an empty dependency array, the callback will only run once after the component mounts: when rendered for the first time.

Make sure to pick ,, followed by [].

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can add any variable inside the dependency array. Now, useEffect with dependencies only runs when those dependencies change.

Set the state variable search as the dependency for the useEffect hook to make it run whenever search is updated.

Make sure to pick , followed by [ and then search, ].

lessons.title: Lesson #5
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also add multiple dependencies.

This useEffect hook runs every time either currentTemperature or desiredTemperature changes.

Make sure to pick , followed by [ and then currentTemperature,, desiredTemperature, ].

lessons.title: Lesson #6
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use as many useEffect hooks as we want.

They help us make the components more modular by isolating different side effects based on specific dependencies or lifecycle stages.

Make sure to pick useEffect followed by [] and then useEffect, useEffect, [count].

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do you ensure useEffect only runs once after the initial render?

Pass an empty array as the second argumentUse a number sign (#) before the arrow functionCall useEffect twiceReturn a function from useEffect

Pass an empty array as the second argument.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a clock that updates every second using useEffect and useState.

Make sure to pick setInterval, followed by 1000.

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a component that logs a message in the console every time its state changes using useEffect.

Make sure to pick [value].

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which dependency array ensures that useEffect only runs when the count state changes?

[count][][state][useEffect]

Make sure to pick [count].

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
Build a component that displays a welcome message once when the component mounts using an empty dependency array.

Make sure to type [].

lessons.title: Lesson #13
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a component that logs the state whenever isOn is changed.

Make sure to type [isOn].

lessons.title: Lesson #16
lessons.interactiveContent:
What will happen if a component using useEffect has no dependency array?

The effect will run after every renderThe effect will never runThe effect will only run onceThe effect won't run until unmount

The effect will run after every render.

lessons.title: Lesson #1
lessons.interactiveContent:
The useEffect hook in React is powerful for managing side effects in components.

When a component unmounts (removed from UI) or dependencies change, any ongoing work should be *cleaned up, preventing potential bugs.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
A cleanup function is a function that we return from useEffect, ensuring that side effects are correctly dismantled.

This function will run once the component is removed from the user interface.

Make sure to pick return, followed by () => {, and finally }.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
The cleanup function will be called when the component unmounts, logging Cleaning up after the spell.

This function will run once the component is removed from the user interface. See it in action by changing the component with the button.

Make sure to pick return followed by ( and then ), =>, {, }.

lessons.title: Lesson #3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's look at a real use case: a countdown timer.

Save the interval in a variable to clear the interval in case the component gets unmounted.

Make sure to pick timer followed by setInterval and then clearInterval, timer.

lessons.title: Lesson #3 - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We only care about the timer when we display the component. We avoid any unexpected surprises by cleaning up when we hide the timer.

See it in action by changing the component with the button.

Make sure to pick return, followed by clearInterval(timer);.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
How can you run a cleanup function in useEffect?

By returning the cleanup function from useEffectRunning it before the component mountsPlacing it inside the dependency arrayCalling it inside the render method

By returning the cleanup function from useEffect.

lessons.title: Lesson #15
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a component that starts a timer when it mounts and stops it when it unmounts.

Make sure to type [].

lessons.title: Lesson #9
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the cleanup function in useEffect help prevent?

Bugs like memory leaksFaster renderingIncreased power usageImproved styles

Bugs like memory leaks.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a component that uses useEffect to add and clean up an event listener on the window object, logging window resize events.

Make sure to type return.

lessons.title: Lesson #11
lessons.interactiveContent:
In the following code, what will happen when the component unmounts?

The interval will be clearedThe count will reset to zeroThe component will crashThe timer will continue running

The interval will be cleared.

lessons.title: Lesson #12
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use useEffect to log a message to the console when the component mounts and a different message when it unmounts.

Make sure to pick useEffect, followed by return, and finally , []).
